content:
This PR has gone through various rounds of review and has an approval, but has stalled for the past 3 weeks. (Nimbers are a quite niche topic, so hopefully an approval by someone else familiar with them counts for something)

#16877
I'm curious if its possible to define the multiplication computably using well-founded recursion
Nimber is a type alias of Ordinal, which is a quotient of Type, which holds no computational data.
Ah, I guess this is out of scope anyway since Add is defined analogously

You could in theory computably define nimber addition and multiplication on a type like docs#ONote, but the easiest way to achieve that would be to not use the direct definition, but rather the characterization in terms of powers of 2
The API all looks good, though I worry slightly about the heavy use of all_goals and <;> in the proof, which I suspect makes them harder to fix when things break

Just reduced the number of all_goals to 2. One of them is for the very symmetric proof mul_comm, which unfortunately can't be separated into a * b ≤ b * a and b * a ≤ a * b without breaking the induction. The other one in mul_add essentially delegates the entire proof to abel (so if that breaks, we're probably in bigger trouble).
Violeta Hernández has marked this topic as resolved.
